description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: March 11, 2020: With Bulletin N. 107, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health participated in a meeting with Health Ministers of other European countries including Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, The Netherlands, Poland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and UK. During the conference call, each State provided an update on the local epidemiological situation and outlined the measures adopted to fight the COVID-19 emergency.

description: Danish government announces that From May 27 2020, high schools, adult education and language centers can reopen. This means the oldest school children, from ages 16, can return to school before the summer holiday. However, students in the last year of high-school will not return to school. Likewise, universities remain closed and continue to teach online.    Evening, music and cultural schools, scouts, as well as outdoor amusement parks and summer activities for children and young people can also reopen.

description: Announced on August 24, 2020, by the Danish Health Ministry,  health authorities recommend that the physical presence in upper secondary education be limited so that a maximum of half of the students are physically present at the school at the same time. The restriction applies provisionally until 4 September 2020. It will be the management of the educational institution that is responsible for ensuring that, before physical attendance at the educational institution begins, plans have been drawn up for how the teaching can be carried out in accordance with the health authorities' recommendations when physical attendance is opened. The Danish Agency for Education and Quality (STUK) advises the management of the institutions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description:
Announced on November 09, by the Danish Health authorities, students at institutions of higher education in the affected municipalities will move to online teaching and have exams not requiring physical attendance. This also applies to students at institutions of higher education in Aalborg who are resident in the affected municipalities.
In exceptional cases, physical attendance may be required. In those situations, everyone is expected to pay close attention to not attend if they have symptoms, to hand hygiene, cleaning, social distancing and to wear a face mask.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: On 7 November 2020 the Minister for Children and Education, the Minister for Education and Research of Denmark announced an Order on special restrictions for daycare, schools, and institutions. Daycare intuitions and schools must ensure 1) a heightened awareness that no one shows up with symptoms of illness, hand hygiene, cleaning, distance requirements, and face coverings in common areas 2) that activities, teaching, etc., which take place in person are in strict compliance with the Danish Agency for Patient Safety's specific instructions regarding education.

description:
Denmark, Jutland, November 5, 2020
Class levels 5-8 move to distance learning in all primary schools. Other grade levels in primary school may be present, but the requirement for a distance of 1 meter must be complied. description: According to an order on special restriction by the Minister for Children and Education, the Minister for Education and Research of Denmark, starting from 13 November 2020, in private and public primary schools, including 10th-grade schools, activities where students are mixed across classes and grade levels may not be carried out. Tests, exams, etc. can be organized with a cross-sectional composition, if such are generally organized in this way, as the school must, however, endeavor to ensure that tests, exams, etc. are carried out as far as possible without a cross-sectional composition.

description: The Danish Prime Minister imposed a partial lockdown in 38 municipalities from December 9, 2020, to January 3, 2021. description: On February 3, 2021 it was announced that starting February 8, 2021 extension of exceptions to school closures so that the following can remain in person as necessary: 1) Students with exams that require physical presence; 2) Pupils who are covered by requirements for language tests; 3) Students enrolled in boarding schools, school homes, etc; 4) Students in youth education for young people with special needs; 5) Young people who participate in the Training School's Labor Market Educations; 6) Participants in health education and courses which are deemed necessary to qualify employees to be part of the health professional preparedness for handling covid-19; 7) Limited participants in labor market trainings.

description: Effective March 1, 2021 Schools will be allowed to partially reopen in some areas of the country, but not in others. Final year students at elementary schools, upper secondary schools and further education (not universities) can now physically attend classes in North Jutland and West Jutland. Classes will return at 50 percent capacity, meaning that students will attend every other week. At elementary schools, students over the age of 12 will be asked to take a Covid-19 test twice weekly but it will not be mandatory. However, students at the other education types will not be allowed to attend without taking a test."

description:
In January 19, 2021 it was announced that The Danish Health Authority's health-related priority order for the rollout
- Persons who live in nursing homes, etc.
- People aged ≥ 65 years who receive both personal care and practical
help
- Persons aged ≥ 85 years
- Personnel in the health, elderly and selected parts of the social sector at particular risk of infection, or who carry out a critical function.
- Selected persons with conditions and diseases which entail a particularly increased risk of severe course of COVID-19
- Selected relatives of persons with a particularly increased risk of a serious course or relatives who are an indispensable care or care person
- Persons aged 80-84 years
- Persons aged 75-79 years
- Persons aged 65-74 years
- People under the age of 65 who have conditions and illnesses that lead to an increased risk of a serious course of COVID-19
- Personnel who carry out other socially critical functions
- Other population, e.g. segmented by age

description: According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order: Residents in nursing homes and people aged 65 years or older who receive both personal care and practical assistance; Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society; Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19; Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.

description: The Danish Health Authority announced on the 4th of February 2021 the New vaccine from AstraZeneca will be the third in the Danish vaccination program. The first deliveries of the COVID-19 Vaccine AstraZeneca® will arrive in Denmark in weeks 6-8 (From February the 8th 2021), and they will initially be offered to people under the age of 65 in priority group 4, which are personnel in the health, elderly and selected parts of the social sector with particular risk of infection or who carry out a critical function. Revaccination takes place in weeks 10-12.

description:
On June 18, 2021 it was announced that the government of Denmark has stared a plan for the vaccination of people unable to get the vaccine. Some citizens find it difficult to access a vaccination pass when they have been vaccinated against COVID-19. This may be because they e.g. are homeless or in temporary residence and do not have an address or a Nem-ID which gives access to the vaccination pass.
A plan has now been put in place for how the vulnerable groups can gain access to a vaccination pass. The plan describes the groups of people in Denmark who must have special help to obtain a vaccination passport. For each group, what the individual can do when the vaccination is completed is described.

The national board of Healt of Denmark announced that citizens who are 85 years of age or older will already be offered the covid-19 vaccination from mid-September 2022 UPDATE: There is no need for more booster shots against covid-19 this season
Both international research and Danish data show that you are well protected against serious illness from covid-19 if you have had a booster shot during the autumn and winter of 2022/23. The Danish Health Authority has therefore decided that no further booster vaccinations will be offered this season from the 1st of February

description: Announced on March 6, 2020 at a press conference in the Prime Minister’s Office, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is now making changes to the travel advice abroad. Countries that had been classified as green, are now labeled as yellow. This means now all travel advice to all countries is now at the minimum yellow. Yellow means to follow precautionary measures, like following the Danish Health Authority's advice to reduce the risk of being infected, staying up to date on health conditions and local government’s measures on Danish embassies' websites as well as through local authorities, news media and your travel agency, checking the travel advice for the country you are traveling to or through and checking travel insurance. "Yellow" does not mean that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs advice against traveling to the area.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From May 25 2020, people with a permanent residence in one of the five Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) or Germany will be allowed to re-enter Denmark if they fall into the following categories:
People who own a summer house in Denmark
Persons who have a relationship with a person living in Denmark or who are engaged to a person living in Denmark
People who have grandparents in Denmark
Business trips to and from Denmark if they are carried out responsibly in terms of health, may be resumed if the applicable precautionary measures are followed. Business trips must comply with industry-specific security precautions.
Except for the above, general family visits, tourism trips, business trips, study trips or similar are not grounds for entry into Denmark that are worthy of recognition.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Announced on June 04, 2020, by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Denmark has issued new guidelines for essential business travel during the pandemic. As a plan of further re-opening restrictions on essential business travel is relaxed. 
Nevertheless, only essential travel is recommended. All returning travelers will be offered COVID-19 tests.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: The government of Denmark is enforcing a restriction of external borders: Denmark closed its borders to all but Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel after March 14. The closures will be in effect until April 13. UPDATE: The external border restrictions that was set to last until May 10 and now has been extended to June 01, when the policy has ended due to different meausres.

description: Announced on June 23, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs continues to label all third countries (non-EU/Schengen countries) as orange, thus advising against all travel from and to these countries. Therfore, the total border crossing ban for third countries is continued at least through August 31, 2020. UPDATE: Announced on July 01, 2020, the Danish government decided on lifting beloved people from the total border crossing ban of third countries. Therefore, lovers, grandparents, and grandchildren are now excluded from the border closure. The country’s government clarified that citizens of Ireland, Malta, Portugal, Romania, the UK and Sweden (except the region of Västerbotten) are not included in this decision.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On 29 May 2020, the Danish Prime Minister announced that border restrictions will be lifted from June 15 for tourists from Germany, Iceland and Norway that have booked a stay of minimum six nights outside of Copenhagen and Frederiksberg. 

The Danish borders remain closed to all but these groups, Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel. UPDATE: Border closures extended to August 31. The Danish border closure - imposed on March 14 and scheduled to be in effect until June 1 - was extended to August 31.  This ban applies to all foreign tourists coming to Denmark, except for those permanently living in Germany, Norway, and Iceland who - effective June 15 - will be permitted to enter Denmark if they have a lodging reservation outside of the Copenhagen region for six nights or more. UPDATE: The original policy imposed on March 14 and scheduled to be in effect until June 1 - was extended to August 31.

description:
From May 25 2020, people with a permanent residence in one of the five Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) or Germany will be allowed to re-enter Denmark if they fall into the following categories:
People who own a summer house in Denmark
Persons who have a relationship with a person living in Denmark or who are engaged to a person living in Denmark
People who have grandparents in Denmark
Business trips to and from Denmark if they are carried out responsibly in terms of health, may be resumed if the applicable precautionary measures are followed. Business trips must comply with industry-specific security precautions.
Except for the above, general family visits, tourism trips, business trips, study trips or similar are not grounds for entry into Denmark that are worthy of recognition. UPDATE: On 29 May 2020; the Danish Prime Minister announced that border restrictions will be lifted from June 15 for tourists from Germany, Iceland and Norway that booked a stay of minimum six nights outside of Copenhagen and Frederiksberg as well as for those people, the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On Thursday, 2 July, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark will implement a new travel advice model for countries outside of the EU/Schengen and UK (also known as “third countries”). The travel advice will be eased for countries that both meet the EU’s new COVID-19 criteria for entry into the EU and do not have significant entry restrictions or quarantine requirements for incoming Danish travellers.

The model for opening the borders and easing travel advice for countries in the EU, the Schengen area and the UK is still in place since the 27 June.

description: Many Danish seafarers are currently stranded on ships all over the world because the COVID-19 pandemic prevents them from making crew changes. After discussions with the industry, the government is therefore now presenting a solution so that seafarers can get ashore safely. The new scheme ensures that seafarers who need it can obtain a visa to enter or leave Denmark under controlled conditions so that they can either get off or on ships at home or in other countries. Denmark will be ready to receive the seafarers under the temporary scheme within 14 days valid from 20 July.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As regards entry into Denmark, as of Saturday 31 October 2020 at 00:00, persons residing in all EU, Schengen and UK countries, with the exception of Estonia, Finland and Norway and certain regions of Sweden, will require a recognised purpose of entry into Denmark. This means that these countries and regions will be considered "open" for the purposes of the entry rules. It should be noted that residents of 'high risk' countries entering Denmark for a recognizable purpose must present a negative COVID-19 test taken at least 72 hours before the time of entry. Read more about the testing requirement, including the exceptions, and current 'high risk' countries at the National Police.

description: From November 11, 2020 Denmark adopts a new guideline. A regional approach to travel guides is being introduced today in the EU and Schengen countries, as well as the United Kingdom.  At the same time, the health authorities' new main recommendation enters into force. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs updates the travel guides for the EU and the Schengen countries as well as the United Kingdom on a weekly basis on the basis of the latest infection figures from the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control  ECDC . For those countries that provide regional test data to ECDC, it will be possible to open for travel to low-risk regions in quarantine countries. Travel to high-risk regions in open countries may also be discouraged. In addition, all unnecessary travel to countries with significant entry restrictions is discouraged for travelers from Denmark. The assessment of whether a country or region is open or quarantined also includes a number of technical criteria regarding test frequency, positive percentage and data availability.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

The entry rules are updated weekly according to the list released by ECDC.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description:
Denmark extends stricter entry restrictions for foreigners residing in the United Kingdom : 

In light of the proliferation of a new mutation of COVID-19, the government introduced stricter entry restrictions for UK residents from 25 December 2020 to 3 January 2021. The stricter restrictions mean that aliens residing in the UK as the clear starting point is denied entry into Denmark.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On December 22, 2020 it was announced that the Danish government introduced stricter entry restrictions for foreigners residing in the UK. This means that foreigners residing in Great Britain will be refused entry if they wish to enter Denmark.
Danish citizens staying in the UK are exempt from this measure and are allowed to enter Denmark. Moreover, workers of freight transport are also lifted from the total border crossing ban
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Effective from December 25, 2020 : For some countries, all unnecessary travel is discouraged due to both too high infection rates and entry restrictions for travelers from Denmark. This applies to: Belgium, Estonia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, the Netherlands, Norway, the United Kingdom, the Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary and Austria.  UPDATE: Target of the policy has changed: Effective from 1st of January 2021; For some countries; all unnecessary travel is discouraged due to both too high infection rates and entry restrictions for travelers from Denmark. description: As of 1 January 2021, the United Kingdom will no longer be covered by the Danish model for entry restrictions and travel guides for EU and Schengen countries. Instead, the United Kingdom will be included in the Danish model for entry restrictions and travel guides for third countries. The change is due to the fact that the UK, due to Brexit, will be considered a third country in relation to EU law per. January 1, 2021, when the transitional arrangement expires.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective from 1st of January 2021, For some countries, all unnecessary travel is discouraged due to both too high infection rates and entry restrictions for travelers from Denmark. This applies to: Belgium, Estonia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary and Austria. The rule is updated weekly according to the list is shared by ECDC. UPDATE: The qualitative nature of the policy type has changed: From Friday 8 January until 17 January; the travel guide for the whole world will be sharpened from being 'orange' (all unnecessary trips are not recommended) to 'red'. That is; all travel to the whole world is discouraged. The tightening takes place as part of the infection management with coronavirus / COVID-19 in Denmark; where restriction of travel activity is an important element in the effort to control the spread of infection; while mutations of coronavirus occur in several countries. The tightening of travel guides means that business travel; which is otherwise considered necessary travel; is also discouraged.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (without the UK),Schengen Area (without the UK)

description: On January 5, 2021 it was announced that In order to minimize the spread of infection with the new mutations of COVID-19 from South Africa as much as possible, from 6 January 2021 up to and including 17 January 2021, the government will introduce stricter entry restrictions for foreigners residing in South Africa. description: From Friday 8 January until 17 January, the travel guide for the whole world will be sharpened from being 'orange' (all unnecessary trips are not recommended) to 'red'. description:
Citizens of all countries have been banned from entering Denmark from January 9 until January 18, as part of the country’s efforts to prevent the further spread of the Coronavirus pandemic, precisely due to the new mutation of the virus found in Britain and some other countries. UPDATE: Announced on January 15, new exemption have been made for entering Denmark, thus the original policy has ended
- Persons resident outside of Denmark can enter Denmark with a worthy purpose and proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry. Please note that persons traveling to Denmark by air, must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before boarding the plan
-Persons residing in the border regions Schleswig-Holstein, southern Sweden (Blekinge and Scania) and West Sweden (Halland og West Gothia) who have a worthy purpose with traveling to Denmark, must present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than seven days before entry. 
- Persons residing in the border regions, who do not have a worthy purpose with traveling to Denmark, must present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

- Persons resident outside of Denmark can enter Denmark with a worthy purpose and proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry. Please note that persons traveling to Denmark by air, must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before boarding the plan
-Persons residing in the border regions Fin, southern Sweden (Blekinge and Scania) and West Sweden (Halland og West Gothia) who have a worthy purpose with traveling to Denmark, must present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than seven days before entry.

description:
On January 15, 2021 To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test until the end of 7 February 2021. UPDATE: Announced on January 15, these groups are also exempt from testing:
Persons, who enter Denmark in connection with the transportation of freight, are exempted from the test requirement – except if the person is residing in the
United Kingdom or South Africa, in which case, the traveler must present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry.
Persons in transit - the entry must take place without undue delay.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Initially, the Government introduced stricter requirements for persons entering Denmark from the border regions, including Schleswig-Holstein, southern Sweden (the provinces of Blekinge and Scania), and western Sweden (the provinces of Halland and West Gothia). This entails that persons who enter Denmark with a worthy purpose must be able to present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry. Under the rules applicable so far, the test must have been taken no more than seven days before entry.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 19, 2021 it was announced that the government has now decided to intensify border efforts at the Danish-German border, where the police, among other things, will close a number of border crossings and switch to significantly intensified border control. The intensified efforts apply temporarily in order to clarify the situation south of the border.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 15, 2021 To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test until the end of 7 February 2021. description: As of October 29, 2020, Within the EU/Schengen countries and the UK, the Department of Foreign Affairs of Denmark is now advising against all non-essential travel to Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom and Vatican City due to the infection figures. UPDATE: geographical target has changed: Announced on April 20, 2021, the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs starts reopening borders for Iceland and some Norwegian regions, including Nordland, Trøndelag, Troms, and Finnmark, also for countries out of the yellow list.  All persons entering Denmark from one of these areas will not be required to self-isolate upon entry and will be allowed to travel without an essential purpose. This measure starts on April 21, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description:
Effective from December 18, 2020 : The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided against the EU's recommendations for opening of these third countries: Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South
Korea and Thailand. This means that for Denmark, these countries are still labeled orange and thus are dicouraged from traveling. UPDATE: restrictions were lifted, thus the policy has ended: Announced on April 20, 2021, the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs lifted all restrictions on entries from these non-Schengen countries:
Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. All persons entering Denmark from one of these areas will not be required to self-isolate upon entry and will be allowed to travel without an essential purpose. This measure starts on April 21, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 21, 2021, the Danish government will begin to ease the external border restrictions, applying color-coded classification to countries based on their risk levels. All travelers must still, upon arrival, present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to travel. Most travel from outside the EEA, with the exception of that from Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, will be prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Announced by the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on Wednesday, April 28, 2021, India turned red in the travel guides due to the presence of a particular virus variant.
The exception in the travel advisories for Fully vaccinated and previously infected persons do not apply to travel to Red countries and regions. This is because countries and regions are categorized as red on due to worrying virus variants.

If you are not fully vaccinated, you are still subject to the requirement for testing and isolation after entry and the requirement for testing prior to boarding flights to Denmark.

description: On February 19, 2021 it was announced that the government has now decided to intensify border efforts at the Danish-German border, where the police, among other things, will close a number of border crossings and switch to significantly intensified border control. The intensified efforts apply temporarily in order to clarify the situation south of the border. UPDATE: As announced on April 28, 2021, by the Danish Police, the intensified border control and the ban on crossing the German-Danish border will be lifted from now on due to decreased infection rates in Flensburg.

description: Announced on May 01, 2021, the former ban on flying to Denmark with passengers without a negative corona test is now extended until and including 13 May 2021.In contrary to former extensions of this policy, now fully vaccinated Danes and foreigners who have a vaccine certificate issued in an EU or Schengen country and who enter from yellow and orange countries are exempt from the requirement to test prior to boarding. The time horizon for the test requirement for a negative test prior to boarding is extended from 24 hours to 48 hours.

description:
Announced on May 12, 2021, the ban on flying to Denmark with passengers without a negative COVID 19 test is now extended until and including 10 June 2021.

In contrary to previous extensions of this policy, now the flight ban is relaxed so that pre-boarding testing is not required in yellow countries and regions.
The age limit for testing requirements is raised to 15 years
Foreign Danes who are fully vaccinated with an EMA-approved vaccine in a country outside the EU or Schengen area are exempt from the requirement to test prior to boarding if they enter from yellow and orange countries or regions.

- Persons vaccinated in Greenland or the Faroe Islands are also not required to present a negative test prior to boarding if they enter from yellow and orange countries or regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on June 08, 2021, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs updated the list of country-specific travel restrictions entering Denmark.The following countries from the EU and Schengen Area are labeled as yellow countries: Austria, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Malta, Poland, Portugal, Romania, and Slovakia. This also includes the following regions: Croatia: Jadranska Hrvatska; France: Corse, Martinique, Mayotte; Greece: Peloponnisos; Norway: Rogaland, Møre og Romsdal, Norland, Viken, Vestland; Spain: Galicia, Principado de Asturias, Cantabria, Extremadura, Comunitat Valenciana, Illes Balears, Región de Murcia, Canarias; Switzerland: Zug, Ticino. A test is required if unvaccinated, travellers are free to travel if they are vaccinated or were previously infected (3G rules)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Announced on June 05, 2021,  the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, updated the list of country-specific travel restrictions entering Denmark.
The following countries outside the EU and Schengen Area are labeled as red countries: Bangladesh, Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, South Africa, Zambia, Zimbabwe, India, Nepal. There  is a total border country ban on these red countries. The list is valid until June 12, 2021.

description:
Announced on June 05, 2021, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has updated its list on travel restrictions.
Travellers from third countries "yellow/"orange"/"red" who were previously infected or are  vaccinated can travel into Denmark without test,
the rest needs a test (3G). Note, that red and orange countries are only allowed to enter Denmark when being classified as an exception.

description: On June 9, Denmark’s government decided to tighten its COVID-19 restrictions imposed on arrivals from the UK due to the new virus variant. In response to the rapid spread of the Delta version in the United Kingdom, Denmark’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has called on its citizens to avoid non-essential travel to Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen, Bolton, and Rossendale. According to Denmark’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, it will be effective until June 26.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on June 19, the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs updated its list on country-specific external travel restrictions. Yellow-labeled countries now include Albania, Australia, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Rwanda, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, USA. Also these Regions: Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Kina. A test is required after entry, and foreigners are required to take a test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate). This counts for people who are not vaccinated nor have previously been infected with COVID-19. There are no restrictions to vaccinated travelers.

description: On July 02, 2021, Denmark announces: Foreigners who hold a valid residence are permitted entrance to Denmark regardless of their purpose unless they are residents in a red country. In that case, they can only enter Denmark if they have a special worthy purpose. Red countries are Bangladesh, Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, India, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, and Nepal. South Africa, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Russia, Scotland, Chile, Surinam, Uruguay, Columbia, Paraguay, Argentina, Costa Rica, Panama, and Namibia. Special purposes include diplomats, crew and shipping members, persons transporting reight, primary caregivers of minors, and persons related to or in a relationship with a dying person in Denmark.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Announced on June 18, 2021, Denmark has ranked the US, Albania, Lebanon,  Northern Macedonia, Serbia, Taiwan, Hink Kong, and Macao as yellow in its new travel restrictions, meaning US residents can now travel to Denmark for tourism even if they have not been vaccinated. These countries no longer need a worthy purpose for entrance. Travelers from these countries and regions also no longer need to show a negative coronavirus test before boarding their plane or isolate on arrival. Nevertheless, a negative Covid-19 Test is required upon entrance upon arrival and foreigners are required to take a test prior to entry to Demark .

description:
Announced on June 24, by the Danish Minsitry of Transport, the travel ban of flying without a negative Covid-19 test, imposed on, January 07, 2021, is now eased: As a result of the gradual reopening of travel, adjustments have been made to the flight ban aimed at making travel easier in Europe:

The flight ban is relaxed so that pre-boarding tests are only required when departing from red countries and regions.
The test requirement is extended from 48 hours to 72 hours prior to boarding, but in return the test must be a PCR test.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Announced on June 24, 2021, by the Ministry of Transport, regardless of the country of departure, foreigners with permanent residence abroad must still be able to present a negative PCR test taken no later than 72 hours before entry to Denmark or a negative antigen test taken no later than 48 hours before entering Denmark. However, this test does not have to be presented when boarding flights to Denmark, but can be checked at the airport upon arrival.

The relaxation will take effect on June 26. The flight ban is extended until 31 October 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On January 15, 2021 To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test until the end of 7 February 2021. UPDATE: geographical target has changed, thus the policy has ended. Announced on June 26, 2021, by the Danish Ministry of Tranport, the travel ban on flying to Denmark, without a negative test will be relaxed on 26 June to only apply to red destinations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on July 06, 2021, Denmark imposes external border restrictions on red and orange-labeled countries. These countries must have a worthy purpose for entrance and have to self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation period can be ended early following a negative test on day four of isolation or following a negative test on entry if the visit to a red country was between 5-10 days ago.

description: On July 02, 2021, Denmark announces: Foreigners who hold a valid residence are permitted entrance to Denmark regardless of their purpose unless they are residents in a red country. In that case, they can only enter Denmark if they have a special worthy purpose. Red countries are Bangladesh, Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, India, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, and Nepal. South Africa, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Russia, Scotland, Chile, Surinam, Uruguay, Columbia, Paraguay, Argentina, Costa Rica, Panama, and Namibia. Special purposes include diplomats, crew and shipping members, persons transporting reight, primary caregivers of minors, and persons related to or in a relationship with a dying person in Denmark. UPDATE: Announced on July 16, 2021, the geographical target for red countries has changed, thus the policy has ended. Cuba, Malaysia, Libya, Tunisia, and Iran were added to the list of red countries. Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, Bangladesh, India, and Nepal were removed from this list.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Announced on June 19, 2021,the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs updated its list on country-specific external travel restrictions. Red-labeled countries now include Bangladesh, Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, India, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Nepal, South Africa, Zambia, Zimbabwe and these red regions in the UK: Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen, Bolton, Rossendale. A test is required prior to boarding an aircraft, a Test is required upon arrival, Isolation is required upon arrival, foreigners are required to have a worthy purpose for entry and foreigners are required to take a test prior to entry. UPDATE: Announced on July 16, 2021, the geographical target has changed, thus the policy ended. Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, Bangladesh, India, and Nepal were removed from this list and added to orange labeled countries. Cuba, Malaysia, Libya, Tunisia, and Iran were added to the red list, together with these regions: Great Britain: West Midlands, East Midlands, South West, South East, London and East of England and Northern Ireland (all of Great Britain except Wales)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has found coronavirus in a mink herd in North Jutland. Based on a precautionary principle, the herd will be culled. The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has analyzed samples from a total of 34 minks from the herd. The Food and Drug Administration encourages mink owners to contact their veterinarian if they suspect coronavirus in their mink herd; effective from June 17th, 2020.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from June 18th, 2020, Denmark is launching a health tracker app called "smittestopp" that enables to monitor the health status of Danish citizens.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On 18 June, the Danish Infection Stop app was launched. With the app, citizens can notify other users if they have been close if one is tested positive. Unlike other infection detection tools, in the app, users can notify other users that they don  t know and warn others that they may have been exposed, so they can be tested. If in the app you are notified that you have been close to a person who has tested positive, you must follow the recommendations of the National Board of Health for close contacts and among other things, stay home and get tested as soon as possible
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry),Other population not specifed above

description: On May 15, 2020 it was announced that A majority of the parliament agreed to develop an app in a public-private partnership. The app will track citizens who voluntarily decide to use the app, and if a citizen using the app is diagnosed with COVID-19, all citizens who have been close to the patient will be informed that they may have been exposed to COVID-19, but the identity of the patient will not be revealed to them. The app was implemented on June 18.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time

description: On December 12, The Danish Agency for Patient Safety requires those passengers who came from UK should monitor their health and self-isolate for the 48 hours. After collecting data and monitoring, Staten university finally examined all visitors until September 1. The Statens Serum Institut expects to come up with updated figures on the occurrence of the new virus variant in Denmark during 23 December.

description: On December 30, the Swedish Agency for Patient Safety states that health monitoring measures like infection detection is moving into Denmark's largest quick-test center in the Park in Copenhagen. It is taking place from locations including at Islands Brygge, in the Jonstrup camp and Ballerup. Copenhagen Medical can scale up to test 3,000 people per hour in the Park, makes it an obvious place for the Agency for Patient Safety to establish infection detection.

description: Announced on August 14, 2020, by the Danish Police, in regard to a further reopening strategy, ongoing efforts are made to optimise the impact of measures and ensure sufficient capacity for testing, tracking and tracing outbreaks. To this end, the Government will set up additional laboratory facilities in Western Denmark operated by Testing Centre Denmark (TestCenter Danmark) to reduce the transportation and response times when testing. It is a clear target that 80 per cent must have access to COVID-19 testing within 24 hours and that 80 per cent will receive a test response the day after the test.

description: The Danish Health Authority has sent out a new national clinical recommendation for consultation, which deals with the use of the medicines tocilizumab and baricitanib for the treatment of children and young people, adults, and pregnant and breastfeeding women with covid-19. The recommendation is expected to be completed in August/September.

description: On 24th of January 2023 The Danish Health Authority gave a recommendation on the use of Blood-thinning medication (thrombosis prophylaxis). It is given to prevent blood clots in hospitalized patients with severe or critical covid-19 disease. The recommendation is the following: High-dose treatment is recommended for adults, pregnant and breastfeeding women with severe covid-19 disease who need preventive blood-thinning medication. In contrast, it is not recommended to use high-dose treatment for adults, pregnant women, and those who are breastfeeding with critical covid-19 disease.

description: The Danish Health Authority has sent out a new national clinical recommendation for consultation. It concerns the use of the drug sarilumab for the treatment of children and young people, adults, and pregnant and breastfeeding women with covid-19. There are both recommendations for and against using sarilumab to treat covid-19, depending on the patient group and the degree of disease. The recommendation for the use of the drug sarilumab to treat covid-19 is in consultation until Monday 14 November 2022. description:
On May 12, 2020 it was announced that The government published more details about the new test strategy. The strategy now contains two "tracks" for testing:
-Track 1 (“the health care track”): testing of referred citizens with COVID-19 symptoms, citizens in hospitals and health care personnel (this track is organized by the five regions)
-Track 2: ("the societal track"): testing of asymptomatic "close contacts", citizens selected for random sample testing, social care personnel, etc. This track is organized by national authorities and takes place in temporary COVID-19 test facilities in 16 locations throughout the country.
 UPDATE: The testing became available for all
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on May 14, 2020, the Danish Health Agency has defined close contacts and the underlying testing strategy for these. If you are a close contact to someone infected with corona, you must call your own doctor, emergency service or emergency telephone to book an appointment for testing.The first test will be performed no earlier than on day four, after you have been in contact with the infected person. The subsequent test is two days after the first. However, if you have tested positive at the first, you do not need to be tested again.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description:
Announced on July 28, 2020, by the Danish Health Authority, when identified as a close contact of a person with COVID-19, contact Coronaopsporing (Corona Tracking), a division of the Danish Patient Safety Authority, for testing. Visit coronaprover.dk to schedule two tests:
First test: Book the earliest available time, at least four days after the initial close contact. If living with the infected person, book the first test immediately.
Second test: Schedule this test two days after the first one. If more than six days have passed since the last close contact, only book one test.
For testing assistance, call Coronaopsporing (Corona Tracking) at tel. 32 32 05 11.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:

You should be particularly alert to possible symptoms of COVID-19 for a period of 14 days after having 
had close contact with the infected person – even if you have tested negative
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Announced on July 02, 2021, by the Danish Health Authority, If one is informed to be a close contact of someone who has tested positive for novel coronavirus, one should have a test done as soon as possible, even when having no symptoms. 
Therefore, one must act as if infected until one has had the result of the test, following these steps:
One must:
Contacting Coronaopsporing, a division of the Danish Patient Safety Authority. They will refer to the person for testing.
Visit coronaprover.dk to book testing appointments.
Scheduling the first test as soon as possible, at least four days after the initial close contact.
If one had prolonged contact with the infected person, one should book the first test right away.
Scheduling the second test two days after the first test.
Note: If it has been more than six days since the last close contact, one only need to book one test.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: Denmark's national infectious agency SSI is going to test people using a new testing method. The focus will be on detecting the United Kingdom's variant B117.Positive Covid-19 PCR tests will be sent for further analysis using a so-called DeltaPCR test, according to DR.

description: Announced on January 22, 2021, by the Danish Ministry of Justice, an agreement between the Minister of Justice and municipalities has been made, to turbocharge mobile testing units. At a meeting with the country's mayors on Thursday, there was an agreement on the importance of using rapid tests even more in the largest daycare centers, care centers, and social services. Therefore, it was agreed to get the mobile test vehicles out to a much greater extent in the country's municipalities in response to a decreasing quantity of mobile capacity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 7 July 2020 the National Government of Denmark announced that In Denmark, testing for COVID-19 is widely available, and anyone can make an appointment for testing, even if they have no symptoms. If you have symptoms, you must contact your doctor to be referred for testing at one of the hospital's test clinics. If you have no symptoms but have been summoned for a test, you must be tested at one of Testcenter Denmark's test stations. UPDATE: Announced on January 26, 2021, by the Danish health authorities, the testing facility has changed. Thus the policy ended.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on April 06, 2020, the authorities are currently working on upscaling the capacity for testing for the novel coronavirus to perform more offensive testing in connection with the upcoming controlled reopening of the Danish society. The tests to be performed during the initial testing phase are diagnostic tests, but concurrent efforts will be made to try out and introduce so-called immune tests, which can detect COVID-19 antibodies.

description:
Announced on April 13, 2021, by the Capital Region of Denmark, that if one  feels unwell – but not ill enough to talk to a doctor, one can book a corona test on coronaprover.dk. Also, when the person is not a Danish national. It is necessary to book an appointment.
One can get tested for COVID-19 as a Danish national resident abroad also if that person has no symptoms or mild symptoms.

description: On 26 January 2021, the health authorities of Denmark announced that citizens should be tested for COVID-19 if they have symptoms, have been in close contact with an infected person, need to be tested for hospitalization or treatment, or as part of outbreak detection. Private suppliers offer free rapid tests, but they are less reliable than PCR tests. UPDATE: On 21 April 2021; Danish Health Authorities announced new guidelines concerning this policy, thus the original policy ended. Citizens should take a PCR test if they have symptoms or if they are the close contact of someone infected with the coronavirus. In other situations; it might be a good idea to take a rapid antigen test.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: Announced on May 17, 2021, by the Danish Health Authority, it is recommended to get PCR tested, when having symptoms that could be COVID-19, or if you learn you are a close contact of someone who is infected with novel coronavirus. Also prior to to hospitalisation, treatment or examination.  This also includes vaccinated people with COVID-19 symptoms. This guideline is not recommended for people who have health conditions that prevent PCR testing. UPDATE: Announced on June 04, by the Danish Health Authority, this policy was exteded until further notice.

The Regional Council will choose the appropriate hospital or facility, and the police may assist in enforcing these orders. This measure goes into force on March 18. 
 UPDATE: Announced on April 04, 2020, this measure is extended until further notice. According to paragraph 6, authorities and health care professionals are now obliged, upon request to provide information to the Danish Patient Safety Authority.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Announced on January 20, 2021, to prevent the spread of COVID-19, the Danish Health Authority has been given the power to establish rules on the disclosure of personal data by individuals and organizations. This includes rules on processing personal data for antigen, PCR, and other tests that detect SARS-CoV-2, as well as rules for the notification of test results. The Health Authority can also establish rules on the disclosure of personal data for gene sequences or sample material from these tests. This measure is repealed on March 01, 2021.

description:
On 21 April 2021, new coronapa (PASSPORT) rules came into effect, where people who have previously been infected are now considered immune for 14-180 days after a positive test.
The Corona passport can be used as documentation for whether a citizen is, respectively:

Fully vaccinated
Tested negative within 72 hours (both PCR and antigen test)
Immune due to a past infection with Covid-19

description: The National Board of Health recommends that in future the corona passport should only be valid for 7 months after the 2nd injection for everyone over 18 years of age. The change in the corona passport will come into effect in mid-January 2022.

description:
Announced on April 09, 2020, by the Danish Ministry of Health, Danish Health Authority has prepared materials with guidance on how to relate to the new everyday life. The materials are aimed both at school and daycare staff and at parents and students. This should answer many questions in response to the controlled reopening of schools and daycare centers after Easter.
The material contains:
Leaflets: With information for employees at schools and day care centres and youth education about the Danish Health Authority's guidelines.
Movies for kids: how to get back to school
Letter in e-Boks to parents with children in daycare centers and schools about the reopening of schools
Posters with advice and recommendations: Posters for schools and daycare centers with good advice for children and parents.
Coursesconsists of three chapters that can be completed in the first days after the opening of the school. It is designed to cover the Danish Health Authority's guidelines on school opening and the topics that students must have knowledge about at start-up.

description: Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020.

description: Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. Anybody that has been in close contact with someone who is known to be infected by SARS-CoV-2 is placed in home quarantine as well. Quarantine in those cases is enforced for 14 days. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020. UPDATE: The original quarantine for those in close contact with someone infected by the virus was 14 days, it has been changed so that these people should self-isolate until they have received 2 negative COVID-19 tests results. These should be submitted/taken om the 4th and 6th day of isolation, and once these have been verified, the person can exit their self-isolation.

description: On March 17, 2020 it was announced that All Danish travelers returning to Denmark, regardless of travel destination, are strongly recommended to stay at home for 14 days. UPDATE: Danish authorities updated their travel recommendations/restrictions on the 15th of June 2020. All countries but Germany, Iceland and Norway remain orange, which means that passengers entering Denmark from all other countries but these three are strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. UPDATE: On June 15 2020 the policy target has changed

description: Denmark is enforcing a voluntary Quarantine on all travelers from risk areas who returned to denmark after March 2 2020. description: The Ministry of Health of Faroe Islands announced on Mar. 28th, 2020, that in the Faroe Islands, all corona positive people should now go into a 14-day quarantine, and that the previous guidelines regarding 48 symptom-free hours no longer apply. description: As of the 13th of March 2020, Danish authorities are categorizing all countries as minimum orange. This means that ALL travelers entering the country are strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon entering Denmark. The policy will be effective for one month and has been given the preliminary end date of April 13 UPDATE: The previous quarantine guidelines were set to last until the 10th of May 2020. The recommendation for 14 days of self-isolation upon returning to Denmark from abroad was, on the 9th of May 2020, extended to the 31st of May.

description: From the 14th of May 2020, Denmark is requiring all those who have been in close contact with a person infected by COVID-19 to self-isolate until they themselves receive a negative test result.

description: From the 14th of May 2020, Denmark is requiring all those who have been in close contact with a person infected by COVID-19 to self-isolate until they themselves receive a negative test result. UPDATE: The original policy only recommended people who have been in close contact with an infected person to self-isolate until they themselves have received a negative test-result. The update policy now encourages all close contacts to self-isolate until they have received two negative test results, one on the 4th and 6th day upon last seeing the infected person.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of the 13th of March 2020, Danish authorities are categorizing all countries as minimum orange. This means that ALL travelers entering the country are strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon entering Denmark. The policy will be effective for one month and has been given the preliminary end date of April 13 UPDATE: On the 29th of May, the Danish Government released plans for a re-opening of the borders and re-introduced the color code for travel restrictions. This new policy will be effective as of the 15th of June, which means that the existing all orange-policy is no longer active
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Danish authorities updated their travel recommendations/restrictions on the 15th of June 2020. All countries but Germany, Iceland and Norway remain orange, which means that passengers entering Denmark from all other countries but these three are strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. UPDATE: The list of countries from where travelers are encouraged to self-isolate upon arrival to Denmark was updated on the 27th of June 2020 and a new policy was introduced - separating EU/Schengen (and UK) countries from the rest of the world. This means that all travelers from outside the EU/Schengen (and UK) are still strongly encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days, whilst the restrictions/recommendations for travelers from a EU/Schengen (and UK) country will depend on the level of contamination in said country, which will be updated on a weekly basis by Statens Serum Institut and Udenrigsministeriet.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From July 9 to July 30, Ministry of Foreign Affairs state that if you return home from a trip to Sweden, you are still encouraged to stay home for 14 days because Sweden does not meet the criteria for low infection rates. description: Denmark is introducing a new regional model for their travel restrictions/recommendations for the EU and Schengen (and UK) countries. As of the 27th of June 2020, the quarantine recommendations for travelers from these countries will be updated on a weekly basis based on the rate of spread of the corona virus. Travelers form orange countries are strongly recommended to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival to Denmark. Effective on June 27, the following countries are classified as orange: Malta, Ireland, Portugal, Romania, Sweden and the UK. UPDATE: The geographic target for the policy was changed on July 23. Effective on July 25, travelers from Portugal, Sweden, Bulgaria and Luxembourg are encouraged to self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival to Denmark.

description: Danish parties reached an agreement on phase 4 of the reopening. Effective on August 14, the agreement noted that authorities carry out targeted information, prevention and risk-based random checks, in accordance with the principle of proportionality, on compliance with health authorities' calls for self-isolation. If self-isolation is not complied with, steps can be taken to isolate the infected by means of orders in accordance with current legislation.

description: In response to the spread of COVID-19 in the country's mink farms, Denmark presents new guidelines and recommendations for residents in the following seven municipalities; Hjørring, Frederikshavn, Brønderslev, Jammerbugt, Vesthimmerland, Thisted and Læsø. As of the 9th of November, the Health Ministry is encouraging all those who work or live with someone who works at a mink farm with verified spread of the virus to stay at home and self-isolate until the contaminated livestock has been terminated and removed from site.

description: As of the 21st of December 2020, Denmark is encouraging all passengers traveling from the UK to self-isolate for 10 days or until they have received a negative test result 4 days upon entering the country. description:

description: Announced on July 06, 2021, Denmark imposes quarantine measures on red and orange-labeled countries. These countries must have a worthy purpose for entrance and have to self-isolate for 10 days after entry. The isolation period can be ended early following a negative test on day four of isolation or following a negative test on entry if the visit to a red country was between 5-10 days ago.

description: Danish authorities updated their travel restrictions/recommendations on January 8 2021. Based on an assessment of the global rate of coronavirus spread, all countries are categorized as red, which in practice means that Danish authorities are discouraging all travel outside of the country's borders and that everyone entering Denmark should self-isolate for 10 days, an isolation that can be broken on the 5th day upon providing a negative PCR test. The policy is in effect as of January 8 and has been given a preliminary end date of January 17 2021.

This instead of the "normal" self-isolation period of 6 days verified by two negative test results. UPDATE: The special recommendations regarding people in close contact with someone infected by the B.1.1.7 virus variant were removed on February 3. description: Denmark updated their guidelines for people who have been in close contact with someone infected by COVID-19 on the 3rd of February 2021. These people should self-isolate and take two COVID-tests, on the 4th and 6th day upon last seeing the infected person. If both of the test results are negative, the person can exit their isolation on the 6th day.

description:
Denmark updated their guidelines for people who have been in close contact with someone infected by COVID-19 on the 3rd of February 2021. These people should self-isolate and take two COVID-tests, on the 4th and 6th day upon last seeing the infected person. If both of the test results are negative, the person can exit their isolation on the 6th day. UPDATE: Announced June 10, 2021 People are fully vaccinated and have contact with infected people no need to go to self isolation. However should get tested on the 4th and 6th day after the last close contact with the infected person.
if there are symptoms of COVID-19, still go for self-isolation. 

 UPDATE: The original quarantine required self isolation for all people had contact with infected people. New update lets vaccinated people to avoid the quarantine

local municipality might offer you an out-of-home stay at a suitable facility.

description:

The isolation can be ended on the 4th day of isolation is the person has submitted a negative PCR test on that day. UPDATE The governmentin Denmark has said that current restrictions for arrivals from outside the Denmark, which were set to finish on April 5th, will also be extended until at least April 20th 2021. 
This includes a flight ban on anyone unable to present a negative Covid-19 test and a 10-day mandatory quarantine period. UPDATE: The government in Denmark has said that current restrictions for arrivals from outside the Denmark, which were set to finish on April 5th, will also be extended until at least April 20th 2021.

description: To cope with the increasing risk that the B.1.351 coronavirus variant will spread in the border regions, the Danish Government introduced stricter rules on entry, including testing and self-isolation requirements, for persons arriving in Denmark from the border regions. Effective on February 13, persons entering Denmark from abroad must, after entering Denmark without undue delay, isolate at an isolation place for 10 days and may not leave the place of isolation before the end of the period. It is possible to interrupt isolation by a negative PCR test for COVID-19 taken no earlier than on the fourth day after the time of entry into Denmark.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 21 April, entry from the following countries/regions of the EU and Schengen countries will be opened: Iceland (the whole country), Norwegian regions: Nordland, Trøndelag, Troms and Finnmark.
It will be possible to enter into Denmark from these countries/regions from 21 April without any requirement for worthy purposes, just as travellers from these countries/regions will be exempted from the isolation requirement after entry. As a result of national reviews of the EU country list, travellers from the following third countries may enter into Denmark from 21 April: Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand. All persons entering Denmark from a country placed on the yellow list will be exempt from the isolation requirements. Travellers from countries and regions that are categorized as orange have to go self-isolation after the entry.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK)

description:
From 21 April, entry from the following countries/regions of the EU and Schengen countries will be opened: Iceland (the whole country), Norwegian regions: Nordland, Trøndelag, Troms and Finnmark.
It will be possible to enter into Denmark from these countries/regions from 21 April without any requirement for worthy purposes, just as travellers from these countries/regions will be exempted from the isolation requirement after entry. As a result of national reviews of the EU country list, travellers from the following third countries may enter into Denmark from 21 April: Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand. All persons entering Denmark from a country placed on the yellow list will be exempt from the isolation requirements. Travellers from countries and regions that are categorized as orange have to go self-isolation after the entry. UPDATE: From the 1st of May 2021, people who are residents in Denmark or in orange countries of the EU/Schengen area are exempt from requiring a test or needing to self-isolate on returning to Denmark. However, children aged 15 to 17 years must continue to be tested after entering Denmark. People who have not previously been infected and vaccinated have to go self-isolation after the entry. Thus,  the demographic target of original policy was changed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: From the 1st of May 2021, people who are residents in Denmark or in orange countries of the EU/Schengen area are exempt from requiring a test or needing to self-isolate on returning to Denmark. However, children aged 15 to 17 years must continue to be tested after entering Denmark. People who have not previously been infected and vaccinated have to go self-isolation after the entry. UPDATE : The requirement for people entering Denmark to have a worthy purpose for their visit is being discontinued for all foreigners residing in orange EU and Schengen countries. This means that tourists from EU and Schengen countries, among others, will be also able to enter Denmark. They will still be subject to post-entry testing and isolation requirements unless they are vaccinated or have been previously infected. The isolation requirement will lapse on 26 June (phase 4) for persons entering Denmark from orange EU and Schengen countries. UPDATE: The original policy only targeted the residents of Denmark and EU/Schengen Countries. The demographic target has changed to all residents and travellers from these countries

description: From the 10th of June in Denmark people who are fully vaccinated or previously infected with a new coronavirus (except in cases where it is a particularly contagious variant ) and have contacted infected people do not need to go to self-isolation. However, should get tested on the 4th and 6th day after the last close contact with the infected person. If there are symptoms of COVID-19, those people still go for self-isolation. People who are not vaccinated or previously infected still have to go to 10 days of self-isolation.

description: From the 10th of June in Denmark people who are fully vaccinated or previously infected with a new coronavirus (except in cases where it is a particularly contagious variant ) and have contacted infected people do not need to go to self-isolation. However, should get tested on the 4th and 6th day after the last close contact with the infected person. If there are symptoms of COVID-19, those people still go for self-isolation. People who are not vaccinated or previously infected still have to go to 10 days of self-isolation. UPDATE:The updated guidelines recommend that in connection with each case of infection, detection of close contacts and close contacts of the close contacts is now initiated. There is no longer a distinction between which variant of virus you are infected with. In the revised version, close contacts must continue to go in self-insulation and be tested twice, while the close contacts of the close contacts can be content with testing and do not have to self-insulate. UPDATE: The original policy targeted everyone in close contact with infected people. A new plan is initiated that changes the target of the policy

description: According to the update which entered into force on September 4, Denmark requires travelers who have not been fully vaccinated or previously infected with the virus arriving from the US, Israel, Kosovo, Lebanon, Montenegro, and North Macedonia, among orange countries of EU/Schengen region, to undergo COVID-19 testing before and stay self-isolated for ten days. UPDATE: The decision has been announced by the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which updated the list of restrictions on  10th of September 2021, and noted that the following six countries have now been removed from the green list of the Danish authorities to the orange one: Albania, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brunei Darussalam, Japan, Serbia. The change means that travelers reaching Denmark from these countries must be vaccinated in order to be eligible to enter. Those who have recovered from the Coronavirus in recent months are also eligible to enter. Upon arrival to Denmark, the same must also undergo a second test after entry and stay self-isolated for ten days. The previous decision made for the traveler arriving from U.S. and Israel is still in place as these countries are in the orange list.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Danish Health Authority tightens guidelines for tracing and handling close contacts and close contacts of close contacts in situations where infection with the new virus variant Omicron is confirmed or suspected. The tightening is being introduced temporarily on the basis of a risk assessment from the Statens Serum Institut on 26 November 2021.The new stricter guidelines mean that all close contacts and the close contacts of close contacts, regardless of vaccination or previous infection status, go into self-isolation. The self-isolation can be lifted again with a negative response to the last test on the 6th day.

description: Danish Health Authority tightens guidelines for tracing and handling close contacts and close contacts of close contacts in situations where infection with the new virus variant Omicron is confirmed or suspected. The tightening is being introduced temporarily on the basis of a risk assessment from the Statens Serum Institut on 26 November 2021.The new stricter guidelines mean that all close contacts and the close contacts of close contacts, regardless of vaccination or previous infection status, go into self-isolation. The self-isolation can be lifted again with a negative response to the last test on the 6th day. description: In 18 September 2020, In the context of rising numbers of Covid-19 in Denmark, the government announced increased restrictions nationally. The opening hours of restaurants, bars, cafes and similar establishments with the required licences will be limited to 10.00 pm.  It is also no longer possible for establishments to stay open from 10.00 pm to 5.00 am to host private parties attended by people largely familiar to each other. Public and private employers are encouraged to ensure that all social events at and in connection with workplaces are cancelled.  These measures will apply in Denmark until at least 4 October 2020.

description: On December 16,  Denmark’s 98 municipalities (mostly located in North Jutland and South Jutland) will come under the country’s ‘partial lockdown’ coronavirus restrictions, which includes restaurants, bars, cafes, gyms, sports centres and swimming pools. Indoor areas at amusement parks, zoos, aquariums and similar types of attractions, as well as at museums, theatres, cinemas and libraries, are also closed to the public. School children from 5th grade upward were sent home for online education. Educational institutions, like upper secondary schools (gymnasier) and universities, were also effected. The restrictions are set to remain in place until January 3rd, 2021.

description: On 30th of January, 2021, the Danish Government announced that citizens are still being encouraged to work from home due to ongoing lockdown measures. Durable goods stores, shopping centers, department stores, and other non-essential businesses must remain closed. Additionally, certain professions that cannot maintain safe distancing measures, such as hairdressers, massage therapists, tattooists, and driving schools, are also required to stay closed. The policy is in place until the 28th of February, 2021.

description: On February 02, 2021, a  new bill requires employers employing incoming workers to ensure that incoming workers are PCR tested for COVID-19 after entering Denmark. The bill also requires employers and self-employed persons without employees who are incoming workers to ensure that they are PCR tested for COVID-19 after entering Denmark. It is proposed that the Danish Working Environment Authority supervises compliance with the requirement. The policy is in place until the 1st of July, 2023.
